title: Tamar Lakes Walking Route

images.title: Philip Halling / Tamar Lake
images.caption: Lake viewed from the footpath and track to the west of the lake.

images.title: David Hawgood / Dam on Upper Tamar Lake
images.caption: View from the upper lake dam

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Upper Tamar Lake dam
images.caption: Upper Tamar Lake dam. From the car park looking north-east. A couple of wind-surfers on the lake.

images.title: David Hawgood / Bird hide, Lower Tamar Lake
images.caption: Bird hide, Lower Tamar Lake. These lakes originally provided water for the Bude Canal, and provide drinking water for Bude. The Lower Lake is predominantly managed as a nature reserve as it is popular with many wildfowl, and the bird hide is open to the public.

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Outflow from the Upper Tamar Lake
images.caption: Outflow from the Upper Lake. Looking downstream from the dam with the Lower Lake in the distance.

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Lower Tamar Lake spillway
images.caption: Lower Lake spillway

description: These two pretty reservoirs sit on the border of Cornwall and Devon. The area is popular with water sports enthusiasts with activities including sailing, windsurfing and kayaking. There's also some nice waterside footpaths for walkers to try. You can park at the Lower Tamar Lake and then head north along the River Tamar to the Upper Lake. Then follow a circular path around the upper lake before returning to the car park. There's nice views across the water to some attractive surrounding countryside as you go. You can also look out for various water loving birds from the on site hide at the lower lake.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: There's a nice cafe at the upper lake activity centre where you can enjoy some post walk refreshment.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The lakeside paths make for a fine dog walk though you are asked to keep them on leads.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: To continue your waterside walking in the area head south to visit the expansive Roadford Lake. You could also enjoy a walk to the old railway viaducts in the nearby town of Holsworthy.  The Tamara Coast To Coast Way passes the lakes. The 89 mile route runs from Cremyll in south Cornwall to Morwenstow on the northern coast.  For more walking ideas in the area see the Devon Walks page.
